The question should be also, why is the method private?  The most
obvious reason I can think of is to hide the method from a client class.
If I want to test a method that is private, I usually decide to make it
protected.  That is the easiest and fastest way.  If I still need to
have the method private in order to hide it from clients, I go with an
interface.  In that case I can make sure that the client only uses what
I want to be seen and I am free in the implementation class to have a
more liberal visibility of methods.

 

Andreas

 

 

________________________________

From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of

Sent: Sunday, July 23, 2006 10:18 PM
To: junit@yahoogroups.com
Subject: Re: [junit] How to Test Private Methods Inside a Class

 

Ole Ersoy wrote:

> The file loading part is in a private method, because
> the load routine is specific to the class that is
> being tested, and is therefore not useful in a utility
> library.

Reusability is not the only reason to extract things into their own 
classes, is it?

> So I just wanted to put the load routine in a private
> method and test it there, then call it from the public
> method.

Would putting it into its own class have had any negative effect?

Can you show us the load routine?

Curious, Ilja
